course.subject: CHEM
course.name: Laboratory for General Chemistry II
course.description: This course is the laboratory class designed for students who enrolled in CHEM 1030. Students will perform experiments based on the theory they learned in courses. By conducting experiments independently, students are able to experience the whole process, from pre-lab and studying Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS), to using suitable labwares, experimental techniques and data treatment. Graded P or F.
course.prerequisites: CHEM 1010 OR CHEM 1020

reviews.author: WilliamLeung
reviews.title: CHEM 1055 Laboratory for General Chemistry II
reviews.comment_content:
Identification of Ionic, Covalent and Metallic Bonds  

Colligative Properties: Freezing Point Depression

Titrimetric Determination of Acetic Acid Content

Buffer Solutions (Grouping )

Solubility Product of Calcium Hydroxide

Thermodynamics of Dissolution of Borax

Determination of Half-Cell Potentials

Identification of a Compound: Chemical Properties

Chemical Reactions of Copper
reviews.comment_teaching:
she explains every experiment in great details in the briefing session before we do the experiments.

some of the equations and remarks she made in the briefing are examined in the final writing exams so try to stay focused and markdown any necessary notes you think is important
reviews.comment_grading:
20% lab class performance
40% written assignment
40% final examination

actually, you can obtain full marks in the 20 % lab performance and the 40% written assignment. (60%)

but, there is another 40% mark which is evaluated by a final exam, there are two versions, they are distributed randomly, to ensure you cannot copy from your neighbor.

40 mc and the scope can be found in the lab reports and the remarks she made in the briefing sessions.

be aware of the calculation part and also pay great attention to every line on the lab report, because the questions may involve some priority of procedures.
reviews.comment_workload:
you can leave earlier as long as you finished.
I usually do in 1.5 hour

reviews.author: foreverA0
reviews.comment_content:
Experiment 1: Identification of Ionic, Covalent and Metallic Bonds  

*Experiment 2: Colligative Properties: Freezing Point Depression

Experiment 3: Titrimetric Determination of Acetic Acid Content

*Experiment 4: Buffer Solutions (Grouping is needed)

Experiment 5: Solubility Product of Calcium Hydroxide

*Experiment 6: Thermodynamics of Dissolution of Borax

Experiment 7: Determination of Half-Cell Potentials

Experiment 8: Identification of a Compound: Chemical Properties

Experiment 9: Chemical Reactions of Copper

*Take-home assignment
reviews.comment_teaching: The instruction is very clear. Before every lab sessions begin, the instructor will go through every slides of the ppt and explain in detail. The TA are so willing to help, so just feel free to ask them if you have any questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is very good!!!!
I almost got full marks in every lab reports and the final exam was very easy. You just have to go through the lab manual once before the final. A piece of cake!
Finally, I get an A+ .
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is light. There are only three take home assignments. Pretty easy!

reviews.author: No2BrCHO
reviews.comment_content:
Experiment 1: Colligative properties: Freezing Point Depression
Experiment 2: Determination of an Unknown Diprotic Acid through Volumetric Analysis
Experiment 3: Buffer solutions
Experiment 4: Thermodynamics of Dissolution of Borax
Experiment 5: Electrochemical Cell - Measurement of Cell Potentials
reviews.comment_teaching:
Two videos (introduction&experiment video) are given to watch before the experiment.
Each experiment has a Zoom meeting to help you handle the data and explain how to complete the lab reports.
TAs will help you when you meet difficulties in conducting the experiments.
reviews.comment_grading:
P/F
To get P grade:
• Attend punctually for ALL the experiments
• Performance with reasonable experimental results obtained 5 Lab
• Submit ALL the lab reports
• Average result ≥ 5 points (full score of each lab report: 10 points)
• No more than one lab report scored below 4 points
• Complete 2 quizzes (exclusive if you have taken CHEM1050)
reviews.comment_workload:
Five Lab Reports
Two canvas quizzes (exclusive if you have taken CHEM1050)
The experiments are more complex than those in CHEM1050, but you can still finish each in 2 hours.

reviews.author: rlo.ldl
reviews.comment_content:
- Identification of Ionic, Covalent and Metallic Bonds
-Colligative Properties: Freezing Point Depression
-Determination of an Unknown Diprotic Acid through Volumetric Analysis
- Buffer Solutions
-Thermodynamics of Dissolution of Borax
-Electrochemical Cell – Measurement of Cell Potentials
reviews.comment_teaching:
for online lesson, just watch 2 teaching videos (introduction+experiment part), no hands-on experiments
each experiments has 1 tutorial session (not compulsory, no attendance taken)
reviews.comment_grading:
p/f
-submit all lab reports (6 in total)
-average score >= 5 (out of 10)
-no more than 1 lab report scores lower than 4
-safety test >= 80% (exclusive if you have taken CHEM1050)
-laboratory apparatus test >= 80% (exclusive if you have taken CHEM1050)
reviews.comment_workload:
6 lab reports+2 canvas quiz(could be exclusive)
not really heavy workload

reviews.author: asulike
reviews.comment_content: The course have 9 labs, with 3 of them required take home assignment. The content of the lab is stated by others. It is not difficult and just follow the instructions on lab manual is ok.
reviews.comment_teaching: The introduction part before the start of each lab is good and you can get some main points and which part should be take care for the lab. TA is helpful and don’t worry to ask if you have any problems.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is good at the end. For the lab part (60%), it is easy to get a full mark if you pay attention to your report. For the final exam, I don’t well prepare for it and only have a quick look on the lab manuals. The turn out result is good and I got A.
reviews.comment_workload: It can be considered as no work load at all if you compared with other lab course in the chemistry major. It is not required to do any preparation for the lab. The only workload is that you need to print the lab manual first and must arrive on time. You can pay some effort for the final exam if you aim for A+.

reviews.author: trust.my.review
reviews.title: online p/f
reviews.comment_content:
6 Experiments

Experiment 1: Identification of Ionic, Covalent and Metallic Bonds
Experiment 2: Colligative Properties: Freezing Point Depression
Experiment 3: Determination of an Unknown Diprotic Acid through Volumetric Analysis
Experiment 4: Buffer Solutions
Experiment 5: Thermodynamics of Dissolution of Borax
Experiment 6: Electrochemical Cell – Measurement of Cell Potentials
reviews.comment_teaching:
We are given two teaching videos (introduction part and experimental part) to watch for each experiment. Also, we have tutorial sessions for each experiment where TA explains how to complete the lab report.

Overall, it is very easy to understand and they technically give you the answers
reviews.comment_grading:
To get a “Pass (P)” grade, you have to fulfil ALL the requirements below:

Six Lab Reports: submit ALL the lab reports
average result ≥ 5 points
(full score of each lab report: 10 points)
no more than one lab report scored below 4 points

Safety Test result ≥ 80%
Laboratory Apparatus Test result ≥ 80%
reviews.comment_workload:
Six Lab Report
SafetyTest: 15 MC questions
Laboratory Apparatus Test: 15 MC questions

Timeline of each Experiment:
Read Lab Manual& Watch Teaching Video(~90 min)
Attend Zoom Tutorial by TAs (optional) (~30 min)
Complete Lab Report & Submit on Canvas before Deadline(~60 min)

honestly, you dont really need this much time, i spend around 2 hours for each experiment.

reviews.author: helenbluee
reviews.comment_content:

reviews.author: J.T.
reviews.comment_content:
9 labs:
Experiment 1: Identification of Ionic, Covalent and Metallic Bonds Experiment 2: Colligative Properties: Freezing Point Depression
Experiment 3: Determination of an Unknown Diprotic Acid Through Volumetric Analysis
Experiment 4: Buffer Solutions
Experiment 5: Solubility Product of Calcium Hydroxide
Experiment 6: Thermodynamics of Dissolution of Borax
Experiment 7: Electrochemical Cell - Measurement of Cell Potentials
Experiment 8: Chemical Reactions of Copper
Experiment 9: Identification of a Compound: Chemical Properties
reviews.comment_teaching: For those who took 1050 before, these two courses are kinda similar. Dr. Yeong explains the experiment shortly at the beginning of each lab. Then you do the experiment, and there are always TA to answer you question during the experiments. Dr. Yeong’s briefing could be helpful, but actually just read the lab manual beforehand is nearly enough.
reviews.comment_grading:
20% lab class performance
40% written assignment
40% final examination

Most of students get full mark for the performance part, unless you break something or maybe forget to bring a printed lab manual.
Written assignment means lab report. For each lab, we are required to submit an electronic report on canvas in two days instead of a hard copy (different from 1050).
The final examination is held during the final period, 1 hour, MC only. The exam is not hard at all, going through the lab manual and your reports once before the exam is enough.
For me, I got full mark for performance, of course. And I managed to get full mark in final as well(mean:30.3/40). In the first eight experiment, I had two lower than means and six higher than means. However, I forgot to submit my last report and get 0 for that one (I even finished my electronic report but forgot to submit on canvas, partly because of the fucking study break which is right after my last session). I am so disappointed by receiving an A finally, especially after my full mark final. So please do remember to SUBMIT all the reports on canvas in time.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is fine, read the lab manual before sessions (or you can read it during the briefing) and finish the electronic report after labs (and SUBMIT!!!!!!!!).

reviews.author: Fickdeinemutter
reviews.title: Elementary Lab Course
reviews.comment_content:
Expt 1. Identification of Ionic, Covalent & Metallic Bonds
Expt 2. Colligative Properties: Freezing Point
Depression
Expt 3. Determination of an Unknown Diprotic Acid Through Volumetric Analysis
Expt 4. Buffer Solutions
Expt 5. Solubility Product of Calcium Hydroxide

Expt 6. Thermodynamics of Dissolution of Borax
Expt 7. Electrochemical Cell - Measurement of Cell Potentials
Expt 8. Chemical Reactions of Copper
Expt 9. Identification of a Compound: Chemical Properties
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lab Briefing at the start of every lab session. Dr. Yeong puts in a lot of effort to make her briefing PowerPoint slides. Skills & knowledge are crystal clear, making sure that your mistakes would be minimized.

She is pregnant this semester.
reviews.comment_grading:
Not sure about how good the grading is.

Lab Reports to be submitted online: 40%
Final Exam (all MC): 40%, mean: 30.3/40
Lab Performance: 20%

Lab Reports are rather basic. Scan your datasheet, open a Word Doc, paste it onto it & answer all questions outlined on the datasheet.

Every Lab Report MUST be handed in on Canvas within 48 HOURS of the official end-time of each of your lab session.

As long as you don't break things or spill over solutions in front of a TA, you can get the 20% in full.

I broke a few glass rods & suffered some deductions from the 20%.

You MUST complete ALL experiments in order to pass.

I didn't copy any “sources” & still managed to get 20/20 for three out of the nine reports, above mean for another three reports & below mean a bit for the remaining three reports.

I got below mean by 5 marks in the Final Exam (40%), but still managed to get B at the end.
reviews.comment_workload:
The experiments are straight forward & don't require much rumination. Follow the steps one by one printed on your Lab Manual & you'd be fine.

The experiments are not strenuous except for Expt. 4, which is the ONLY one that you would be assigned a groupmate as you need to measure the pH of seven sets of buffer solutions via a phone app called SPARKvue in wireless connection with a pH probe to be immersed into the solutions. In Expt. 4's lab report, you need to do some really lousy calculations on the solutions' buffering capacities & something relevant to the Henderson-Hasselbach Equation. This is the most troublesome one of all reports of this course.

In the Final Exam, there was at least one question about calculating the buffering capacity. Pay attention to this during revision.

Since I took this course in Year 4 & had already done with the more crazily complicated Syn Lab & MC Lab in previous years, this lab course isn't hard for me.

Many people completed almost every experiment in an hour. I don't know how many of them are really Year 1. I did recognize some Year 3 students in my session.

reviews.author: Hamburger Milk
reviews.title: learn some basic knowledge about labs
reviews.comment_content:
Just easy, basic, teaching labs
9 labs in total

Some of the labs are pretty easy, but some of them are hard.
reviews.comment_teaching: The instructor is not very kind but the teaching is OK.
reviews.comment_grading:
very hard to get A+.
I got the highest score in the final and deduct about 1-2 points in each lab. I got A at last.

If you want A+, you work very carefully, try to get full marks in every lab, get high score in the final (which is very difficult).
reviews.comment_workload:
Just attend the labs.
3 take home lab report.
a little heavy for a 1 credit course.

reviews.author: ds
reviews.comment_content:
Experiment 1: Identification of Ionic, Covalent and Metallic Bonds  

*Experiment 2: Colligative Properties: Freezing Point Depression

Experiment 3: Titrimetric Determination of Acetic Acid Content

*Experiment 4: Buffer Solutions (Grouping is needed)

Experiment 5: Solubility Product of Calcium Hydroxide

*Experiment 6: Thermodynamics of Dissolution of Borax

Experiment 7: Determination of Half-Cell Potentials

Experiment 8: Identification of a Compound: Chemical Properties

Experiment 9: Chemical Reactions of Copper

*Take-home assignment

And the last week is make-up lab. Which you don't need to attend if you never miss any class before
reviews.comment_teaching:
Their pronunciation is not that good. Sometimes it sounds funny and it might make you a little bit confuse on what she's saying. The old TAs are really good, but there are 2 TA (which I don't know their name) who are pretty harsh in giving you score.

They never tell us the detailed thing and it is not being discussed in lecture yet, so you have to find the answer by yourself.
And you can't use your phone to search it in the class. I suggest you do all the questions before the lab HAHAHA.
reviews.comment_grading:
GRADING

20% lab class performance
40% written assignment
40% final examination

It's kinda hard to get all perfect in lab report. But 10 points are free in every performance as long as you don't break anything.
reviews.comment_workload:
It's not heavy. Although the time given for the take home assignment is really short. I have other homework and quizzes dude! Really need to try to make those assignment perfect.

note: Be really careful! I count it wrong in the first part, and it affect my final equation which make me get a bad score ugh.

reviews.author: kyp
reviews.comment_content:
Topics covered
- Liquids and solids
- Properties of solutions
- Acids and bases
- Acid-base equilibria
- Solubility and complex ion equilibria
- Spontaneity, entropy and free energy
- Electrochemistry
- Chemistry of representative elements
- Transition metals

Experiments
- Identification of Ionic, Covalent and Metallic Bonds
- Colligative Properties: Freezing Point Depression
- Titrimetric Determination of Acetic Acid Content
- Buffer Solutions
- Solubility Product of Calcium Hydroxide
- Thermodynamics of Dissolution of Borax
- Determination of Half-Cell Potentials
- Identification of a Compound: Chemical Properties
- Chemical Reactions of Copper
reviews.comment_teaching:
- A short briefing before each experiment.
- Most TAs are nice and more than willing to answer students' questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
- Fair
- The final exam was easy.

20% Lab class performance
40% Written assignment
40% Final examination
reviews.comment_workload:
- The workload is appropriate.
- Only 3 lab reports are take-home assignments. All other experiments require a report to be submitted in class.

No mid-term exams or quizzes.

reviews.author: Minerva
reviews.comment_content:
- Identification of Ionic, Covalent and Metallic Bonds
- Colligative Properties: Freezing Point Depression
- Titrimetric Determination of Acetic Acid Content
- Buffer Solutions
- Solubility Product of Calcium Hydroxide
- Thermodynamics of Dissolution of Borax
- Determination of Half-Cell Potentials
- Identification of a Compound: Chemical Properties
- Chemical Reactions of Copper
reviews.comment_teaching: It was quite difficult to understand her pronunciation. However, it is very important to focus on her saying and jot down notes during briefing as what she said will be on the final exam.
reviews.comment_grading:
Lab performance 20%
Lab report 40% (6 in class, 3 take-home)
Final 40%

If you don't make serious makes, you will get full marks for lab performance. I lost some marks (about 2-3 out of 20-30) for almost every lab report. It is very hard to get full marks every time, so don't be too depressed even if you don't. The final exam result was not announced, but it was pretty easy. You just need to review the lab manual.

Finally I got an A.
reviews.comment_workload: I think workload is a little bit heavy, considering that this is a 1 credit course.

reviews.author: heartattack
reviews.title: Good Grade!!!
reviews.comment_content: This course includes 9 experiments, all the theories in which are learned from CHEM 1030. Each experiment occupies only about 6 pages of the lab manual. Many of the techniques and calculations are related to titration and are taught in high school already.
reviews.comment_teaching: The instructors explains the procedures and principles clearly prior the experiment. Remember to jot down any notes that are in the PowerPoints but not in the lab manual such as some chemicals which are not stated. Listen carefully to the instructions of TAs when they are teaching about the skills of handling glass wares like the proper way to hold a dropper. Many of the above will be examined. Besides, it is better to do pre-lab preparation thoroughly since some TAs may ask you questions suddenly and monitor if you make mistakes through out the experiment.
reviews.comment_grading: My pre-major faculty advisor said he had not seen any students getting B or below in this course. It is very easy to get high marks in every lab report if you have carefully thought about the answers before entering the lab. Read through the lab manual again and that's all for final exam. The final exam consists of about 55 MC questions in 1 hour. It was not too rush because the questions were not so difficult. I got about 18/20 in every lab report and about 6 answers wrong in exam, contributing to A+.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is just appropriate. You are required to do pre-lab preparation every week. The lab reports of 3 experiments are take-home assignments. The only content for final exam is the lab manual, which you have been familiarised with.
